title: Multiplication/Division Properties of Exponents
kid_friendly_explainer: Exponents are a shortcut for repeated multiplication.
Instead of writing 2 × 2 × 2 × 2, we can write \(2^4\).
A letter like x or y can stand for a number. We call it a variable.

core_rules.name: Same base × Same base
core_rules.plain_english: When you multiply powers with the SAME base, keep the base and ADD the exponents.

core_rules.name: Power of a power
core_rules.plain_english: A power raised to another power means MULTIPLY the exponents.

core_rules.name: Power of a product
core_rules.plain_english: If everything is being raised to the same power, each factor gets that power.

core_rules.name: Bonus (division, for comparison)
core_rules.plain_english: When dividing same bases, subtract exponents.

walkthrough: Power of a product: give the 2 to \(x^3\) and \(y^5\).

easy.directions: Use the rule \(x^a × x^b = x^{a+b}\). Keep bases the same and add exponents.

medium.directions: Mix the rules. Tidy by grouping like bases. Watch for hidden exponents of 1 and 0.

items.hint: Power of a product, then simplify.

challenge.directions: Trickier structure: negatives, zeros, and multiple bases. Simplify step by step.

items.hint: Square first: numbers and each exponent; then combine a-powers.
\(y = y^1\). Subtract then add, or add all with signs.
Distribute the 3, then combine like bases.

extreme.directions: Multi-step puzzles. Watch parentheses and order: powers of powers first, then multiply like bases.

items.hint: Raise each factor to its power, then combine exponents per base.
Expand powers, then add/subtract exponents across the fraction.
Inside the parentheses subtract exponents (top minus bottom), then square, then combine with \(x^{-1}\).
\(m^0=1\). Square the middle group, then collect m- and n-exponents.
Expand cubes/squares; combine same bases; simplify the number factor.

teacher_notes: Emphasize: the ADD rule only works when the bases match.
Encourage students to rewrite lone variables as power 1 \((x = x^1)\) and remember \(x^0 = 1\) (for \(x ≠ 0\)).
Have students circle like bases before combining.
